title: Why don't parents respect teenagers’ privacy? - Quora

response.answer_text: Why don’t parents respect teenagers’ privacy? I’ll be honest, I don’t know. I do have a few theories, but we’ll never truly know why parents enjoy invading their children's space and making them feel violated. Actually that’s kind of immature of me. I’m sure they don’t enjoy it, unless they’re sadistic, but it still ain’t cool, am I right? Times have changed, and this is something most parents nowadays don’t seem to understand or want to accept. With the arrival of mobile phones, advanced technology and whatnot, people have changed. I suppose it’s your decision if it was for better or for worse. Good or bad, parents need to start giving their children more privacy. And yes, I understand the whole, “You earn it, it’s not given to you” aspect of all that. I’m not a brat, and can respect that. But parents invading their kids space unwarranted, simply because they feel like they can, is not okay. I’m still a teenager myself, and let me tell you, my parents have put me through hell because of my phone and things related to that. I don’t know how it was when my parents were kids, but it seems to me that everyone knew each other, people called friends on the house phones, everyone was always outside..you get the point. Things are very different now. Neighborhoods aren’t as closely knit, friends are contacted via SnapChat or iMessage, and days are spent inside more than outside. Even more importantly, due to the internet (and this is more of a con then a pro, and this especially applies to me and my friends) kids are losing their innocence much sooner. That includes virginity too. No, I have not yet had sex (I actually want to wait), but I know a great deal about drugs, alcohol, sex, sexual toys, and interactions from the internet, my friends, and personal experience. Not to brag, but I feel like I’m going to be a pretty decent parent if I ever am one, not because I have the most amazing and chill parents ever, but because I know what NOT to do when it comes to raising children. I have experience with what’s annoying and the things I hate, and I’ll apply that to how I raise mine. I won’t take away their phone every five seconds for talking to their friends or just to show them that “I’m in charge.” (My parents do this so much, seriously just to demonstrate that they’re in charge). And no, I’m not going to let them have sex at age 12, you’re not mentally prepared for that type of relationship then, but I won’t flip if I heard they tried weed at a party when they’re 16. Some may disagree, but most relationships between parent-kid are screwed up because parents are too strict and remember how they were raised, and expect their children to be “just like them”; completely accepting of the many rules that they had laid down as kids, getting good grades, etc. Now that we’re in the 21st Century, some of those expectations still apply, but not all. It’s especially annoying when my mom compares me to her. My mother is extremely intelligent and gifted in reading, writing and now mathematics. I am gifted in the art region, but still am smarter than average in reading and writing. She always says she’s so disappointed in me whenever my grades are low (low to her are C’s, when most of my grades are A’s and B’s), or that I’m not “like her” at all. She’s referring to her absolute angel of an attitude when it comes to anything, how she was always sooo respectful and obedient. It makes me so mad sometimes, and it honestly hurts my self-esteem when she says I’ll never amount to much if I’m not as successful as her. No one’s perfect, but she certainly acts like she is sometimes. So to recap: Parents don’t respect their teenagers privacy either because they truly aren’t trustworthy enough for it, or because they have a hard time accepting that times have changed and kids need their space in order to grow and thrive. The human brain needs to make mistakes and hit walls in order to expand it’s knowledge, not just in school but in the real world. If teens spend their whole childhood sheltered and then are suddenly released into the world, when will they make their mistakes and experiment? We need to be able to grow now, before we turn 18. And, if you want to have a relationship with your kid, for the love of God, just give them their space. I promise, if you let them be, they’ll be more willing to come to you when a problem in their personal life arises. If you want to be their go-to, someone they trust, their best friend, and you want to show them you care, leave them alone and let them come on their own time. Thank you and goodnight.

Teen agers only deserve the privacy they have earned. Teens run the homes and that’s not the way it should be. Teens are the offspring of those who have had cortus and produced them. Teens don’t need privacy because they will do things which are unnatural, sexual, or other perverted things. Why don’t parents respect teenagers’ privacy? Because teens can’t handle it. They will tell you what ever you need to hear, then without thinking about it, they have gone against their word to you. Many times, I really don’t feel the teens understand the importance of their actions and the learning curve all humans must tolerate. They are no different. Yes, I believe the teen should be able to close the door. Lock it? I don’t think so especially if someone of the other gender is present. Yes, there is nothing wrong with knocking before entering. It is the parents’ home and they have the right to look in every drawer in their homes, behind every door, and out each and every window. Many a teen has gotten pregnant because mom and dad gave so much privacy they didn’t know what was happening right in front of their faces! Parents only give the privacy to a teen who has shown responsibility and the ability to do as they are asked, ordered, told to do.
